facts.text: Appellants were lessees of a cinema theatre called Prakash Talkies at Ahmedabad

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were lessees of a cinema theatre called Prakash Talkies at Ahmedabad and carried on the business exhibiting cinematograph films in that theatre.

facts.text: Appellants carried on the business of exhibiting cinematograph films in Prakash Talkies

anchor.surface_text: and carried on the business exhibiting cinematograph films in that theatre. After the expiry of the lease the landlord filed an action in the civil court in ejectment against the appellants

facts.text: Lease of Prakash Talkies expired

anchor.surface_text: After the expiry of the lease the landlord filed an action in the civil court in ejectment against the appellants and obtained a decree for possession of the theatre

facts.text: Landlord filed ejectment action in civil court against appellants

anchor.surface_text: After the expiry of the lease the landlord filed an action in the civil court in ejectment against the appellants and obtained a decree for possession of the theatre and an order for payment of mesne profits.

facts.text: Civil court obtained decree for possession of the theatre and order for payment of mesne profits against appellants

anchor.surface_text: and obtained a decree for possession of the theatre and an order for payment of mesne profits. The civil judge at Ahmedabad determined in a proceeding under Order XX, rule 12, of the Code of Civil Procedure,

facts.text: Civil judge at Ahmedabad determined mesne profits liability of appellants at Rs. 2,57,963 under Order XX rule 12 CPC

anchor.surface_text: The civil judge at Ahmedabad determined in a proceeding under Order XX, rule 12, of the Code of Civil Procedure, the liability of the appellants to pay mesne profits at Rs. 2,57,963.

facts.text: In appeal, mesne profits claim settled by consent and reduced to Rs. 1,90,220

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the claim of the landlord for mesne profits was settled by consent and the amount was reduced to Rs. 1,90,220. In proceedings for assessment of income for the assessment year 1955-56

facts.text: For assessment year 1955-56, appellants claimed Rs. 92,240 out of mesne profits as permissible allowance in computation of business income

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment of income for the assessment year 1955-56 the appellants claimed Rs. 92,240 out of the amount of mesne profits as a permissible allowance in the computation of their business income.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim of Rs. 92,240 as business not carried on by appellants during previous year relevant to AY 1955-56

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim holding that the business of Prakash Talkies was not carried on by the appellants during the previous year relevant to the year of assessment 1955-56.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order, holding mesne profits as ex gratia or capital payment not legal charge on business

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer holding that mesne profits which the appellants had to pay for wrongfully using the landlords property must be treated not as a legal charge on the business but as an ex gratia or capital payment.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held that appellants did not prove integrated cinematograph business, outgoing for closed business not admissible

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal it was held that since it was not proved that the appellants carried on an integrated cinematograph business in the manner claimed by them, the outgoing in respect of a closed business was not an admissible allowance.

facts.text: Tribunal found that appellants acquired various theatres on lease or otherwise and ran each independently with separate identifiable books

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal observed that what the appellants were doing is acquiring various theatres from time to time either on lease or otherwise and run each of them independently with separate identifiable books opening of a new theatre of closure of another will not affect the working of the remaining ones.

facts.text: Prakash Talkies had been run independently of other cinemas and source dried up in 1952

anchor.surface_text: This is after all the proper test of an integrated and interlaced business. The Prakash Talkies had been run quite independently of the other cinemas and, as such, a source had dried up in 1952 itself.

facts.text: Tribunal referred two questions to Gujarat High Court, first whether Rs. 92,240 allowable for AY 1955-56

anchor.surface_text: Two questions were referred by the Tribunal to the High Court of Gujarat, the first of which alone need be set out Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the amount of Rs. 92,240 was allowable as a deduction

facts.text: Gujarat High Court answered the question in the negative

anchor.surface_text: in determining the business income of the assessee for the assessment year 1955-56 ? The High Court answered that question in the negative.

facts.text: Appellants appealed to Supreme Court with special leave

anchor.surface_text: With special leave, the appellants have appealed to this court.

holdings.text: For income of a business to be taxable under section 10 of the Act it is one of the conditions that the assessee must carry on the business in the relevant year of account. If the business is discontinued before the commencement of the accounting year, the income attributable to that business received in the year cannot be taxed under section 10, because the source of income had ceased to exist. If the Income of a business is not taxable under section 10 as income of a particular year because the business was not carried on in that year, the assessee can obviously not seek to debit the expenditure incurred for carrying on that business, against his other income, for the outgoings are chargeable only against the income of a business which was carried on in the previous year. It follows that if an assessee carries on several distinct and independent business, and one of such business closed before the previous year, he cannot claim allowance under section 10 of the Act of an outgoing attributable to the business which is closed against the income of his other business in that year.

anchor.surface_text: For income of a business to be taxable under section 10 of the Act it is one of the conditions that the assessee must carry on the business in the relevant year of account. If the business is discontinued before the commencement of the accounting year,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory condition under section 10(1) requires business to be carried on during the accounting year for profits to be taxable and related outgoings to be deductible against business income; no allowance for discontinued business expenses against other business income.

holdings.text: In our view, nosuch broad proposition of law can be accepted. Whether different ventures carried on by an assessee form parts of the same business must depend on the facts and circumstances of each case.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, nosuch broad proposition of law can be accepted. Whether different ventures carried on by an assessee form parts of the same business must depend on the facts and circumstances of each case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Characterization of multiple ventures as single or separate businesses involves application of legal principles to facts, making it a mixed question reviewable by higher courts.

holdings.text: As pointed out by this court in Setabganj Sugar Mills Ltd.s case in determining whether different ventures may be said to constitute the same business it has to be seen whether there was any interconnection, any interlacing, any interdependence, any unity embracing the ventures, and whether the different ventures were so interlaced and so dovetailed into each other as to make them into the same business.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by this court is Setabganj Sugar Mills Ltd.s case in determining whether different ventures may be said to constitute the same business it has to be seen whether there was any interconnection, any interlacing, any interdependence, any unity embracing the ventures,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts precedent from Setabganj Sugar Mills establishing multi-factor test of interconnection, unity of control, interdependence, and interlacing activities to determine if ventures form single integrated business.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts found by the Tribunal it is difficult to hold that the appellants have made out their case that the venture of Prakash Talkies was a part of a general business of exhibiting films in cinema theatres carried on by the appellants.
